title: From Evidence to Policy
text:
Across education, health, sport, work, and crisis management, your research converges on one core message:

How people are motivated matters at least as much as whether they are motivated.

Policies and communication that support people’s basic psychological needs for autonomy, competence, and relatedness lead to:

more sustainable behavior change

better mental health

greater trust and cooperation with institutions

In contrast, controlling or fear-driven approaches may yield short-term compliance but undermine well-being, trust, and long-term engagement.
This page summarizes the main lessons for policy and practice that follow from your body of work, without going into individual studies.

title: From Evidence to Policy
section: 1. Motivating Behavior Change: Quality Over Quantity
text:
1. Motivating Behavior Change: Quality Over Quantity
A recurring finding is that autonomous motivation, acting because one endorses the goal and finds it personally meaningful, predicts:

more persistent adherence to health measures

greater willingness to vaccinate or take boosters

better performance and enjoyment in sport and physical activity

more resilient coping in everyday life and during crises

By contrast, controlled motivation, acting out of guilt, pressure, or fear of sanctions, is associated with:

more fragile, short-lived compliance

higher stress, anxiety, and depressive symptoms

more reactance, resistance, or disengagement when the pressure increases



Policy implications


Frame the “why”, not just the “what”.
Explain the underlying reasons and values behind measures (e.g., protecting vulnerable groups, keeping schools open), rather than simply issuing rules.
Highlight shared goals.
Link behavior (masking, vaccinating, social distancing, climate action) to collective outcomes people care about, not just individual obligations.
Avoid purely controlling levers.
Rewards, punishments, and shaming can erode intrinsic and internalized motivation, especially over time. Use them sparingly and always combined with clear rationale and respect.

title: From Evidence to Policy
text:
2. Communicating in Times of Crisis
Several strands of our work show that how authorities communicate can either support or thwart people’s psychological needs.
Key patterns:

Autonomy-supportive communication (acknowledging concerns, offering meaningful choice where possible, being transparent about uncertainty) is linked to:

higher trust in government
more willing and lasting adherence
better well-being during restrictions

Controlling communication (commanding tone, guilt-inducing, moralizing, or threatening) is linked to:

more need frustration (feeling pressured, incompetent, isolated)
more resistance, reactance, or quiet non-compliance

lower mental health

Even subtle cues like the tone of voice or prosody can signal respect versus domination and thus shape autonomy and closeness.



Policy implications


Use an informational, respectful tone.
Speak to citizens as partners rather than subjects. Avoid humiliating or blaming language.
Acknowledge difficulty and ambivalence.
Naming people’s doubts and fatigue can reduce defensiveness and increase openness.
Be transparent about uncertainty and trade-offs.
Honest communication about what is known and unknown supports competence and trust, even when messages are not “good news”.
Mind the medium and the messenger.
Consistent, credible messengers and coherent narratives across channels (press conferences, social media, local communication) matter for perceived integrity.

title: From Evidence to Policy
text:
3. Designing Need-Supportive Policies and Environments
Studies on education, sport, leadership, and health policy carry a similar message: good structures and rules are not the opposite of autonomy; they are the vehicle through which autonomy, competence, and relatedness can be supported.
Findings across contexts show that:

Meaningful choice within clear boundaries (e.g., options in school tasks, flexibility in how to comply with health guidelines) enhances engagement.
Clear expectations and guidance support competence; ambiguity and constantly changing rules undermine it.
Fairness and proportionality of measures (matching the “weight” of restrictions to the severity of risk) are crucial for legitimacy and motivation.
Need-supportive teaching, coaching, and leadership styles (both in everyday life and under constraints) predict better performance, well-being, and cooperation.



Policy implications


Combine structure with autonomy.
Provide clear rules and timelines, but allow for local or personal flexibility in “how” to implement them.
Ensure proportionality and fairness.
Explain how the severity of measures is calibrated to risk and epidemiological indicators. Perceived overreach can quickly erode trust and willingness.
Design policies for competence.
Make it easy to comply: practical steps, concrete examples, feedback, and support tools (e.g., testing logistics, appointment systems).
Invest in need-supportive leadership.
Train leaders (school heads, coaches, managers, health professionals) to avoid controlling practices and to foster autonomy, competence, and relatedness in their teams and clients.

title: From Evidence to Policy
text:
4. Supporting Resilience and Mental Health
Our work during the COVID-19 crisis, and in other vulnerable populations, shows that psychological needs and emotion regulation are central to resilience.

When people feel connected, effective, and self-endorsing, they show:

fewer symptoms of anxiety and depression
better coping with boredom and confinement
more constructive forms of emotion regulation and self-motivation

Specific groups (parents of children with chronic illness, older adults, people with high caregiving demands, prisoners, adolescents) are particularly vulnerable when needs are frustrated but also benefit strongly from need-supportive contexts.
Integrative emotion regulation strategies (acknowledging and making sense of emotions rather than suppressing them) are linked to growth and better adjustment.



Policy implications


Monitor mental health alongside behavioral indicators.
Track well-being and need satisfaction, not only infection or compliance rates.
Target resources to vulnerable groups.
Offer tailored support for parents, caregivers, late adults, people in unsafe contexts, and those in institutional settings (schools, prisons, hospitals).
Promote healthy self-regulation skills.
Interventions that foster mindfulness, integrative emotion regulation, and self-motivating strategies can reduce the costs of necessary restrictions and stressors.
Think long term.
Policies that repeatedly frustrate needs may have lasting mental health costs, even if they “work” in the short term.

title: From Evidence to Policy
section: 5. Trust, Risk Perception, and Democratic Engagement
text:
5. Trust, Risk Perception, and Democratic Engagement
Across vaccination, conspiracism, and risk perception work, a consistent pattern emerges:

Trust in institutions and perceived integrity interact with risk perception to shape motivation:

realistic risk perception + high institutional integrity → constructive, autonomous motivation
high fear + low trust → defensiveness, conspiracy beliefs, and rejection of recommendations

Attitudes toward measures like certificates or mandates depend not only on content, but on:

perceived fairness
respect for autonomy
perceived consistency with democratic values




Policy implications


Prioritize institutional integrity.
Coherence between message and action, and visible fairness, are as important as the message itself.
Use risk communication as a motivational resource, not a threat.
Help citizens understand risk in ways that invite responsible action rather than panic or denial.
Connect measures to democratic values.
Show how policies can protect freedom and participation in the long run, even when they temporarily constrain behavior.

title: From Evidence to Policy
section: 6. How We Translate Evidence into Practice
text:
6. How We Translate Evidence into Practice
Within the PsySoc Data Hub, these insights are turned into:

Policy briefs on topics such as crisis communication, vaccination campaigns, proportionality of measures, and democratic engagement.
Workshops and trainings for policymakers, educators, health professionals, and leaders on need-supportive communication and design.
Consultancy and co-creation processes, where new policies are designed or evaluated with an eye for autonomy, competence, and relatedness.

The overarching message to decision-makers is:

Policies and communication that respect and support people’s basic psychological needs are not only more humane, they are also more effective and sustainable.

For collaboration or tailored advice, you can connect the dots between specific datasets, sectors (health, education, justice, sport), and the practical questions policymakers bring to the table.

Governance, policy & societal regulation

Public policies and governmental communication shape the extent to which citizens experience societal need support or frustration. These publications examine how proportionality, communication style, trust, and policy design influence motivation, compliance, and public well-being during crises.



  
    
  

  
    
      
        Psychological Science and Its Societal Mission During the SARS-CoV-2 Pandemic:

        This article presents the Motivation Barometer as a real-time tool linking psychological science to COVID-19 policy in Belgium.

        Belgians’ motivation, experiences, and well-being during the COVID-19 pandemic. It illustrates how psychological data were used to inform

        How the Stringency of the COVID-19 Restrictions Influences Motivation for Adherence and Well-Being:
        The Critical Role of Proportionality
      
      
        Waterschoot, J., Morbée, S., Van den Bergh, O., Yzerbyt, V., Raemdonck, E., Brisbois, M., Schmitz, M.,
        Klein, O., Luminet, O., Van Oost, P., & Vansteenkiste, M.
      
      
        International Journal of Health Policy and Management (2023), 12, 8021
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        Using large-scale longitudinal data from Belgium, this study tests how the proportionality between
        COVID-19 restrictions and the epidemiological situation relates to citizens’ motivation to comply
        and their well-being.
      

      
        Across multiple pandemic waves, more than 270,000 Belgian respondents reported on their motivation
        to adhere to COVID-19 measures, their actual adherence, and indicators of mental well-being.
        These data were linked to objective indices of policy stringency and viral circulation over time.
        The study examined whether people felt that the strictness of government measures was proportional
        to the epidemiological risk and how this sense of proportionality related to motivation and well-being.
        When restrictions were perceived as proportionate, people reported more autonomous motivation to comply,
        greater adherence, and better psychological functioning. When measures seemed overly strict or insufficient
        relative to the infection situation, controlled motivation and amotivation increased, and well-being
        deteriorated. The findings highlight proportionality as a key ingredient for sustainable public health policy.

        A Global Experiment on Motivating Social Distancing during the COVID-19 Pandemic
      
      
        Legate, N., Nguyen, T. V., Weinstein, N., Moller, A., Legault, L., Vally, Z.,
        … & Ogbonnaya, C. E.
      
      
        Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (2022), 119(22), e2111091119
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        This large cross-country experiment compares autonomy-supportive and controlling messages
        about social distancing to test which communication strategies foster motivation and compliance
        during the COVID-19 pandemic.
      

      
        In collaboration with the Psychological Science Accelerator, this preregistered experiment
        recruited over 25,000 participants from 89 countries to evaluate different public health messages
        about social distancing. Participants read either an autonomy-supportive message emphasizing
        personal choice and reasons for distancing, a controlling message relying on pressure and guilt,
        or a neutral control message, and then reported their motivation, intentions, and emotional reactions.
        Across cultures, autonomy-supportive communication promoted more internalized, high-quality motivation
        for social distancing and more favorable attitudes, without raising defensiveness. In contrast,
        controlling messages tended to elicit reactance, anger, and lower quality motivation. The findings
        suggest that respectful, choice-affirming communication is a more effective and sustainable way to
        encourage public health behaviors globally.

        The Role of Communication Style and External Motivators in Predicting Vaccination Experiences
        and Intentions: An Experimental Vignette Study

      Abstract

      
        This vignette study examines how autonomy-supportive versus controlling communication, combined with
        external motivators such as incentives or mandates, shapes people’s vaccination experiences and intentions.
      

      
        Participants evaluated hypothetical vaccination messages that varied in communication style
        (autonomy-supportive versus controlling) and the presence or absence of external motivators
        (e.g., rewards, pressure, or requirements). They subsequently reported their emotional reactions,
        perceived legitimacy of the policy, and intention to be vaccinated. Messages that acknowledged
        people’s perspectives, provided meaningful rationales, and preserved a sense of choice promoted more
        autonomous motivation, more positive vaccination experiences, and higher intentions. Strong external
        pressure and controlling language, in contrast, were linked to more negative affect and lower quality
        motivation, even when they sometimes boosted short-term intentions. The findings suggest that respectful,
        autonomy-supportive communication is critical for fostering durable acceptance of vaccination policies,
        particularly when external motivators are used.

text:
Collective health behavior & public safety

Collective safety depends on citizens’ willingness and ability to enact protective health behaviors. The studies in this theme analyze the motivational, cognitive, and contextual factors that guide population-level engagement in preventive actions such as distancing, hygiene behaviors, and risk-responsive behavior.




  
    
  

  
    
      
        Trajectories of Health Behaviors During the COVID-19 Pandemic:
        A Longitudinal Analysis of Handwashing, Mask Wearing, Social Contact Limitations, and Physical Distancing
      
      
        Wollast, R., Schmitz, M., Bigot, A., Speybroeck, N., de la Sablonnière, R., Lacourse, E., & Luminet, O.
      
      
        Psychology & Health (2023), 39(13), 1899–1926
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        This study aimed to investigate the associations between health behavior adherence and psychological factors during the COVID-19 pandemic, with a particular focus on identifying trajectories of handwashing, mask wearing, social contact limitations, and physical distancing.
      

      
       Aim: This study aimed to investigate the associations between health behavior adherence and psychological factors during the COVID-19 pandemic, with a particular focus on identifying trajectories of handwashing, mask wearing, social contact limitations, and physical distancing. Methods: We employed a multi-trajectory group-based approach to analyze data from 6026 Belgian residents, including 60% women, with an average age of 52.65. Data were collected over six waves spanning from April 2021 to December 2021. Results: Participants were categorized into trajectory groups based on persistently low (11.9%), moderate-low (20.9%), moderate-high (39.1%), and high (28.1%) levels of adherence to the specified health behaviors. Our findings indicate a declining trend in health behavior adherence over the study period. Additionally, we observed that females, older individuals, and those with prior COVID-19 infection had a higher likelihood of belonging to trajectory groups characterized by the highest levels of health behavior adherence. Similarly, individuals with positive vaccination intentions, a heightened perception of consequences, and increased health anxiety demonstrated greater adherence to health behaviors over time. Furthermore, our investigation into the relationship between health behaviors and mental health revealed that participants in trajectory groups with higher levels of adherence to social contact limitations and physical distancing reported increased feelings of loneliness and decreased life satisfaction. Conclusions: The COVID-19 pandemic has reshaped our lives, and while vaccines have marked progress, maintaining health behaviors is crucial for virus prevention. To address potential mental health challenges from sanitary measures, policies and communication should promote health behaviors while acknowledging their psychological impact.

        Predicting Health Behaviors During the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Longitudinal Study
      
      
        Wollast, R., Schmitz, M., Bigot, A., Brisbois, M., & Luminet, O.
      
      
        PLoS ONE (2024), 19(3), e0299868
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        We investigated the social, emotional, and cognitive predictors of adherence to four health behaviors (handwashing, mask wearing, social contact limitations, and physical distancing) during one critical phase of the COVID-19 pandemic.
      

      
        We investigated the social, emotional, and cognitive predictors of adherence to four health behaviors (handwashing, mask wearing, social contact limitations, and physical distancing) during one critical phase of the COVID-19 pandemic. We collected data (N = 5803, mean age = 53; 57% women) in Belgium at five time points between April and July 2021, a time during which infections evolved from high (third wave of the pandemic) to low numbers of COVID-19 cases. The results show that the social, emotional, and cognitive predictors achieved high levels of explained variance (R2 > .60). In particular, the central components of behavioral change (attitudes, intentions, control, habits, norms, and risk) were the strongest and most consistent predictors of health behaviors over time. Likewise, autonomous motivation and empathetic emotions (e.g., attentive, compassionate) had a positive impact on health behavior adherence, whereas it was the opposite for lively emotions (e.g., active, enthusiastic). These results offer policymakers actionable insights into the most potent and stable factors associated with health behaviors, equipping them with effective strategies to curtail the spread of future infectious diseases.

        Are There Three Subtypes of Social Distancing? A Longitudinal Investigation of Physical Distancing,
        Social Contact Limitations, and Emotional Distancing
      
      
        Wollast, R., Sadeghi-Bahmani, D., Schmitz, M., Bigot, A., Gross, J. J., & Luminet, O.
      
      
        European Journal of Health Psychology (2025), 32(3), 148–164
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        Social distancing is often used as something of a catch-all category without clear definitions of its subtypes.
      

      
        Background: Social distancing is often used as something of a catch-all category without clear definitions of its subtypes. Aims: We propose that social distancing has three subtypes: physical distancing, social contact limitations, and emotional distancing. Method: To test this hypothesis, we employed a longitudinal design to analyze the trajectories of social distancing subtypes over a period of 8 months during the COVID-19 pandemic (N = 6,026). Three years after the main survey, we recontacted the same participants, asking whether they would be willing to re-adopt social distancing measures in the context of a new pandemic (N = 841). Results: First, using a confirmatory factor analysis, we demonstrated that these subtypes are related but distinct constructs. Second, using group-based trajectory modeling, we identified trajectories of individuals following persistently low, moderate-low, moderate-high, and high levels of social distancing subtypes over time. Trajectories of physical distancing and social contact limitations were highly similar and decreased over time, whereas trajectories of emotional distancing were significantly different from the other two subtypes and showed stability. Importantly, we found sociodemographic and mental health indicators distinguishing these trajectories. Finally, we found that emotional distancing exhibited a stronger and more consistent association with social contact limitations than with physical distancing across studies. Conclusion: This study proposes a refined taxonomy of social distancing, highlighting the distinct subtypes of physical distancing, social contact limitations, and emotional distancing (see items in the Appendix). This new taxonomy has been both conceptually and statistically validated in the present paper and can assist other experts in assessing the construct of social distancing more accurately in future studies.         Theory of Planned Behavior Constructs as Mediators of Relations Between Personality Traits, Trust,
        and COVID-19 Preventive Behavior Adherence
      
      
        Wollast, R., Phillips, J. B., Hagger, M. S., Hamilton, K., DeSmet, A., & Luminet, O.
      
      
        Social Science & Medicine (2025), 384, 118531
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        This article tests whether Theory of Planned Behavior constructs mediate links between personality, trust, and adherence to COVID-19 preventive behaviors.
      

      
       Objective. Dispositional constructs (personality traits, generalized beliefs) are associated with health behaviors, but few studies test potential underlying mechanisms. The current study tested an integrated theoretical model specifying indirect effects of personality traits (conscientiousness, extraversion) and socio-political beliefs (trust in political leaders and health authorities) on initial participation, and subsequent trajectories, in COVID-19 preventive behaviors (handwashing, physical distancing, limiting social contact, mask wearing) mediated by social cognition constructs (attitudes, subjective norms, perceived behavioral control) and intentions. Methods. Belgian residents (N = 1762) completed measures of dispositional and social cognition constructs and intentions for COVID-19 preventive behaviors on an initial occasion and self-reported their engagement in the behaviors on four follow-up occasions from April to July 2021. Model predictions were tested using latent growth curve modeling. Results. Indirect positive effects of conscientiousness and trust in politicians and health authorities, and indirect negative effects of extraversion, on health behavior intentions and initial behavior participation as mediated through social cognition (with minor exceptions). These accounted for non-trivial variance in each outcome. Contrary to predictions, model constructs did not account for variance in behavioral trajectories. Conclusion. The current analysis lends support for the model across behaviors, adding to an evidence base of potentially malleable determinants of COVID-19 preventive actions and a candidate mechanism. How to sustain adherence to COVID-19 preventive actions remains an open question in need of further research. Replication studies in other national contexts and other public health crises are warranted.

      Abstract

      
        This article examines when risk perception functions as a motivational resource rather than a source of paralysis.

Social cohesion, identity & community

Societal challenges test the strength of social bonds and shared identity. These publications explore how loneliness, emotional distancing, identity processes, and cultural factors shape people’s sense of belonging, emotional functioning, and adaptive capacity within the social fabric.




  
    
  

  
    
      
        The Role of Self-Compassion in Loneliness During the COVID-19 Pandemic: A Group-Based Trajectory Modelling Approach
      
      
        Wollast, R., Preece, D. A., Schmitz, M., Bigot, A., Gross, J. J., & Luminet, O.
      
      
        Cognition and Emotion (2024), 38(1), 103–119
      
    

    
      Abstract

      
        Research has suggested an increase in loneliness during the COVID-19 pandemic, but much of this work has been cross-sectional, making causal inferences difficult.
      

      
        Research has suggested an increase in loneliness during the COVID-19 pandemic, but much of this work has been cross-sectional, making causal inferences difficult. In the present research, we employed a longitudinal design to identify loneliness trajectories within a period of twelve months during the COVID-19 pandemic in Belgium (N = 2106). We were particularly interested in the potential protective role of self-compassion in these temporal dynamics. Using a group-based trajectory modelling approach, we identified trajectory groups of individuals following low (11.0%), moderate-low (22.4%), moderate (25.7%), moderate-high (31.3%), and high (9.6%) levels of loneliness. Findings indicated that younger people, women, and individuals with poor quality relationships, high levels of health anxiety, and stress related to COVID-19, all had a higher probability of belonging to the highest loneliness trajectory groups. Importantly, we also found that people high in two of the three facets of self-compassion (self-kindness and common humanity) had a lower probability of belonging to the highest loneliness trajectory groups. Ultimately, we demonstrated that trajectory groups reflecting higher levels of loneliness were associated with lower life satisfaction and greater depressive symptoms. We discuss the possibility that increasing self-compassion may be used to promote better mental health in similarly challenging situations.

        The coronavirus pandemic posed a major challenge to mental health. Existing evidence shows that COVID-19 is related to poor emotional well-being, particularly among women.
      

      
        The coronavirus pandemic posed a major challenge to mental health. Existing evidence shows that COVID-19 is related to poor emotional well-being, particularly among women. However, most work on the subject uses single-country samples, limiting the ability to generalize the disparity or explain it as a function of societal variables. The present study investigates the expression of positive and negative emotions during the pandemic as a function of gender and across 24 countries (N = 49,637). Strong gender differences emerged across countries, with women reporting more negative emotions (anxious, depressed, nervous, exhausted) and less positive emotions (calm, content, relaxed, energetic) than men. The gender gap in positive emotions was significantly wider in countries higher in individualism and narrower in countries higher in power distance. For instance, differences in emotions were larger in Western countries high in individualism, such as the USA, the UK, Italy, and France, and smaller in countries with higher collectivism and power distance, such as China, Malaysia, and South Korea, with a few exceptions like Japan and Brazil. These gender differences across countries were not explained by country-level gender inequalities indicators (GGGI and GII). Interestingly, the national severity of the pandemic, an epidemiological factor, reduced gender differences in positive emotions. These results underscore the importance of considering cultural and national factors when assessing gender differences in well-being.

title: Methodology
text:
Data collection procedures

Online questionnaires administered via secure survey platform Qualtrics.
Participants reached through social media advertisement, newspapers, institutional mailing lists, and partner organizations.
No financial incentives: participation was voluntary and based on informed consent.
Attention checks (“Please, assign option 2 here”) and data quality indicators (e.g., removing all participants having completed the survey in less than 200 seconds) were used to identify low-quality responses.



Data cleaning and processing
Key steps include:

Screening for invalid responses (e.g., extremely short completion time, failed attention checks).
Handling missing data according to pre-specified rules (e.g., minimum item responses for scale scores). - see tutorial how to handle missing data
Recoding and labeling variables consistently across surveys, waves and projects. - see tutorial
Constructing composite scores (e.g., mean scores). - see tutorial
Creating weights for selected waves to approximate Belgian population distributions in age, gender, education, and region. - see tutorial

All major processing steps are documented in reproducible R scripts, available in the GitHub repository and referenced in the tutorials.


Analytic approaches
Analyses conducted with these datasets include:

Cross-sectional regression and structural equation models.
Multilevel models and growth curve models for longitudinal data.
Cluster profile, latent class, and trajectory analyses. - see tutorial
Experimental and quasi-experimental designs embedded in specific waves.
Mixed-method integration with qualitative data.

title: Study designs
text:
Motivation Barometer
The Motivation Barometer is a large-scale, online monitoring study that was launched on 19 March 2020, one day after the first national lockdown in Belgium (2020 - 2023). During the first ten weeks of the pandemic, daily surveys were administered, with a subset of participants followed for ten consecutive weeks. As the pandemic evolved, new waves were organized at a slower pace and adapted to emerging topics (e.g., vaccination, COVID certificate, trust, conspiracy beliefs).

Total waves: more than 110 measurement waves over roughly 2.5 years.

Total responses: nearly 484 000 completed questionnaires.

Unique participants: over 320 000 individuals.

Design: combination of cross-sectional cohorts and longitudinal panels, with targeted subsamples (e.g., students, parents, older adults, athletes, (un)vaccinated individuals).

Each wave combined a core set of variables (motivation, basic psychological needs, adherence to measures) with topical modules tailored to the phase of the pandemic (e.g., attitudes toward mandatory vaccination, perceptions of the COVID certificate, conspiracy beliefs, boredom, loneliness).

title: Study designs
text:
THRIVE Project
The THRIVE project (“Taking stock to foster health and trust for an inclusive post-Covid society”) is a BELSPO funded Post-Covid research programme (2023 - 2026). THRIVE explicitly builds on the Motivation Barometer by:

Consolidating and harmonizing existing Motivation Barometer waves.

Adding new post-Covid follow-up waves.

Integrating complementary qualitative and survey data.

Its core objectives are to:

Chart the social and psychological heterogeneity of the population during the COVID-19 crisis by identifying distinctive trajectories of motivation, well-being, trust, and democratic attitudes.
Examine how these trajectories relate to resilience and vulnerability, including long-term mental health outcomes.
Combine multiple disciplines and methods (health psychology, motivation psychology, social psychology, sociology; quantitative and qualitative approaches).
Identify contextual drivers (e.g., communication style, stringency of measures, trust, ideology) that feed into people’s experiences and reactions.

Welcome to the PsySoc Data Hub: the Psychology & Society Data Hub. This platform serves as a central repository for large-scale datasets on themes regarding psychology and society.  The name PsySoc highlights the mission of the Data Hub: to bridge psychological science with societal topics by fostering collaboration across research domains, practitioners, and policy actors, an essential endeavour both in times of crisis and for society’s long-term resilience.

title: PsySoc Data Hub
text:
About
The PsySoc Data Hub brings together a growing collection of complementary datasets that offer insight into how people navigate societal challenges, adapt over time, and experience the conditions around them. It offers:

📊 A growing collection of high-quality datasets
🧠 Documenting central themes such as motivation, need satisfaction and frustration, well-being, mental health, trust in institutions, adherence, and risk perception, along with the full catalogue of publications derived from these datasets.
🔍 Comprehensive documentation, including codebooks, protocols, methodological notes, and variable descriptions

🛡️ GDPR-compliant controlled access for sensitive data

🧪 Synthetic datasets, tutorials, and reproducible examples for learning and transparent analysis


Current datasets

Motivation Barometer & THRIVE Datasets
At the heart of the hub lies the Motivation Barometer, a landmark monitoring project that followed the psychological functioning of the Belgian population from the earliest days of the COVID-19 crisis. Across more than 110 waves and over 320,000 participants, the project tracked motivation, psychological needs, risk perception, adherence, well-being, and trust.
The THRIVE project builds on this infrastructure, extending it beyond the pandemic with new longitudinal waves and additional qualitative and quantitative data. Together, these efforts create a rich, theory-driven resource for studying resilience, vulnerability, democratic attitudes, communication, and long-term recovery.
Both datasets are integrated into one cohesive data ecosystem, allowing researchers to seamlessly explore trends over time, compare modules, and link psychological indicators to societal developments.


Louvain Foundation Dataset
The Louvain Foundation dataset follows more than 5000 UCLouvain students and Belgian residents across seven waves from 2021–2022, with a follow-up wave in 2025. It gives many information into COVID-19–related perceptions and behaviors (e.g., trust in health authorities, adherence to public health measures), alongside well-being, social connection, emotional responses, and other psychological indicators during and after the pandemic. Fully anonymized by design, it offers a secure and useful resource for research on the social and psychological impact of COVID-19.
